Notes: Pre-1950s {{lang|ga|bliadhain}} in Irish. The form {{lang|ga|bliadhna}} ({{lang|ga|bliana}} today) is used as a special plural form following numerals
column5: the regular plural is blianta). Some eastern Scottish Gaelic dialects use the form {{lang|gd|bliadhn}}[8].

Notes: Also {{lang|ga|réidió}} and {{lang|gd|rèidio}} in spoken Irish and Scottish Gaelic
Pre-1950s genitive {{lang|ga|ríogh}} and dative {{lang|ga|rígh}} in Irish
In Irish, {{lang|ga|eaglais}} is a Roman Catholic house of worship
column5: a Protestant house of worship is called a {{lang|ga|teampall}} (temple). As Gaeilge 'séipéal' is also used as it can mean chapel as well.
